level.ecm_name: Monocrystalline photovoltaic panel connected to the grid
level.description: Photovoltaic (PV) solar technologies generate electricity by exploiting the photovoltaic effect. Light shining on a semiconductor such as silicon (Si) generates electron-hole pairs that are separated spatially by an internal electric field created by introducing special impurities into the semiconductor on either side of an interface known as a p-n junction. This creates negative charges on one side of the interface and positive charges are on the other side. This resulting charge separation creates a voltage. When the two sides of the illuminated cell are connected to a load, current flows from one side of the device via the load to the other side of the cell

level.application: Connected to the electricity grid and displace power that would otherwise be drawn from the grid.
level.advantages: _The solar energy conversion has no emissions during operation_Applications in many orders of magnitude (from some mW to several MW). _Direct and diffuse radiation could be converted in electricity_Silicon is the second most abundant element on earth and is not toxic. _Integration in buildings is possible.
level.disadvantages: _Low convertible energy density._Electricity production depends on weather conditions and irradiation. _There is no good storage facility._The purification of the silicon is an energy intensive (and expensive) process.
